newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bundesbank leaves interest rates unchanged.
newsitem.headline: Bundesbank leaves interest rates unchanged.

text.p: The Bundesbank said on Thursday its council left the German discount and Lombard rates unchanged after its regular meeting.
The German discount rate remains at 2.50 percent and the Lombard emergency financing rate at 4.50 percent. The central bank's main money market rate, the repo, was also held at three percent.
Financial markets had expected the Bundesbank would leave its key rates, including the main money market rate, unchanged, as there were currently no economic pressures demanding a change.

Instead more attention was likely to be paid to the issue of revaluing German assets, two weeks after the Bundesbank rejected Bonn's plans to ask for a transfer of profits in 1997, to be used to pare back debt.

Six out of 10 analysts polled by Reuters on Tuesday said they expected the Bundesbank to approve a compromise solution. However it was not clear whether there would be any official statement on the plan emerging from the meeting.
Waigel last week backed down from a plan to seek a special payout in 1997 from a revaluation of reserves held at the Bundesbank.
